26723620.review:
I purchased this game years ago before it was on Steam, but I recently saw that it's now on Steam so I had to support it with another purchase.

The true genius of this game isn't so much in the gameplay as much as it is how perfectly the game captures that whimsical childhood feeling of going on an adventure in the snow. Exploring, sledding, building snow castles, drinking hot chocolate, rolling around in the snow until it starts to get dark and your mom calls you from the porch that it's time to come inside for the night. The whole thing is done in beautiful hand-drawn art, and the soundtrack is pure magic.

In gameplay terms, it's mainly a fairly casual platformer. There is no fear of death or failure at all, which is what makes it casual. Instead it's mostly about collecting and exploring. Very early you discover some winter elves who grant you the power to glide through the air a bit after a jump. At that point you can begin collecting snowflakes. Every snowflake you collect is sort of like +1 exp and permanently adds a very tiny fraction of extra power to your glide, so your ability to magically soar through the air will get better and better as you collect.

The game has a night/day cycle and you only have until the end of the day to explore before your mom calls you back inside for the evening. So another aspect of the gameplay is creating a path for your sled as you explore. That way, at the start of each new day, you can quickly sled to your last destination without having to take a lot of time to get there.

It's a very relaxing and adorable little game, and in my opinion an example of a game that knew exactly what feeling/atmosphere it wanted to capture and then just nailed it.

Recommended especially if you'd like to play something festive around the christmas season. =]

(Note that the game is small and initially only runs in windowed mode. There is no in-game option for playing in full screen, but you should be able to do it by pressing F11.)

First time players: be aware. This games starts out difficult because you do not have the ability to fly from the beginning. press and hold Spacebar = fly

Marvin's Mittens is a short platformer that has you running around outside collecting snowflakes and looking for Marvin's lost mitten across snowy landscapes.

Snow everywhere, towering pine trees, luminous caves, mountain peaks, the occasional animal, and even elves! 
I launched steam, opened up the game, put away my phone, put my earbuds in, and forgot about the rest of the world (if only for a couple hours).

If there were any more snowflakes to collect, I'd still be playing right now.

This little gem is just pure magic. I don't think I've ever enjoyed a platformer this much in my entire life. The story itself is nothing to write home about; one of Marvin's mittens got stolen and he's looking for it every day. The execution however is top-notch. Everything from the simple but rewarding progression to the music score, voice acting, level design, you name it, were all very well done.

The only (minor) grip I had with the game was the automatic saving system that got in the way of snowflake-hunting more than once by throwing Marvin back home at more-or-less regular intervals. I think I would've liked a disable option for this but I have to admit that it added its own little charm. Moreover, as traveling from map to map got faster, it didn't really bother me.

Overall, I'd say the experience was worth every cent. Absolutely loved it. I can well imagine myself returning to this game in the future.

20290153.review:
[h1]MARVIN'S MITTENS - Zauberhafte Winternostalgie ![/h1]

HANDLUNG: [i]ohne Spoiler[/i]
Die Geschichte im Spiel ist simpel gestrickt. Wir schlüpfen in die Haut des kleinen Marvins, dem beim Spielen im Schnee ein Handschuh geklaut wird. Wenig später treffen wir auf einige Elfen, die uns die Fähigkeit beibringen, durch "Super-Sprünge" große Höhenunterschiede überwinden zu können. Und damit haben wir auch schon alle Voraussetzungen, um uns durch abwechslungsreiche Winterlandschaften auf die Suche nach unserem Handschuh zu machen.

GRAFIK:
Der Look von Marvin's Mittens ist toll ! Das fängt bei unserem unglaublich liebenswürdig designten Protagonisten an und zieht sich auch über die stimmungsvollen, schön gezeichneten Winterlandschaften. Und wenn es dann langsam dämmert und überall Sterne funkeln, dürfte es auch dem letzten Spieler etwas wärmer ums Herz werden. Ein kleiner Wermutstropfen: Das Spiel unterstützt leider keine Full HD-Auflösung.

LEVELGESTALTUNG:
Die Spielwelt des Platformers ist in mehrere überschaubare Areale unterteilt. Die Aufgabe bleibt allerdings immer die gleiche: Wir müssen Schneeflocken einsammeln, um unseren "Super-Sprung" zu verbessern; Kämpfe oder andere Formen von Gewalt gibt es nicht. Optional können wir außerdem Tiere dokumentieren, auf die wir während unserer Reise stoßen. Die Areale sind dabei durchaus abwechslungsreich gestaltet, unterm Strich fällt das simple Sammeln der weißen Flocken, zumindest für meinen Geschmack, aber trotzdem etwas zu monoton aus. Nervig ist außerdem, dass uns Marvins Mutter jede Viertelstunde, also am Ende eines Tages, zurück nach Hause ruft und das Spiel dort gespeichert wird. Trotz Schlitten und Abkürzungen kann einen das doch ganz schön aus dem Spielfluss bringen. Ganz wie früher in der Realität eben auch...        

UMFANG:
Die Spielwelt fällt für den Preis durchaus relativ groß aus. Zwar mangelt es an abwechslungsreichen Aufgaben aber wer sich für das Schneeflocken-Sammeln begeistern kann, ist durchaus 4-5 Stunden beschäftigt. Das Spielende lässt sich übrigens auch erreichen, ohne alle Flocken eingesammelt zu haben.

BALANCE:
Ist Marvin's Mittens ein Spiel für Kinder ? Nun ja, auch. Dementsprechend werden Platformer-Profis keinerlei Probleme mit dem Schwierigkeitsgrad des Spiels haben. Die Steuerung ist eingängig und funktioniert gut, wenn auch nicht absolut präzise. Marvin's Mittens ist kein Spiel, dass frustrieren will. Dementsprechend stimmt die Balance. 

ATMOSPHÄRE:
Der negative Punkt zuerst: Wenn wir uns in ein anderes Areal begeben, dauert das Laden des nächsten Map-Abschnitts relativ lange. Gerade wenn wir mit unserem Schlitten durch mehrere Areale sausen, nagt dieses Problem etwas an der Atmosphäre. Doch das ist Meckern auf hohem Niveau, denn Marvin's Mittens hat es geschafft, mich in frühere Kindheitstage zurückzuversetzen. Der erstklassige Soundtrack, das tolle Artdesign und die eingängige Spielmechanik machen Marvin's Mittens zu einem unaufgeregten und unbeschwerten Winter-Abenteuer !

WEITERES:
Bugs sind bei mir im Spiel nicht aufgetreten.

FAZIT:
[h1]Trotz repetitiver Spielmechaniken fesselt Marvin's Mittens durch seine beruhigende, winterlich zauberhafte Art ![/h1]

WERTUNG: [h1]71[/h1]

Somewhere inbetween love gone wrong, opportunities missed, bad grades and relationships fading, you gradually lost pieces of your heart and the small bits of innocent belief that a better world could be. But your angina decay went so slowly you could not be aware at the time.

Time. You had all the time in the world. Time to find any solution to any mind or heartache presented to you. Time to waste. Time to enjoy.

Now you know how precious time is. But even more, you are painfully aware of how precious any pipe-dream solution to get those bits and pieces back are. Because you are still looking for them and your body cells have long since started to decompose more rapidly than they renew, and your hair is thinning and graying like it's a race to the finish line.

Today you live among hipster d0uchebags hating on anything older than an hour of existence, pathetic script kiddies on your lawn leaving snarky internet comments, sold-out parents with their fake smiles and monster mortgage - everyone pretending to enjoy life after their precious childhood were whisked away. And however faint your hope, you still struggle with the idea that somewhere there has to be a key, a door, or even the tiniest of glimpse back to those wonderful years. And you would again, for a brief moment, enjoy a full, red heart behind your dusty, weathered rib cage.

This game, then, is my gift to you. It's for all the snowmen and snow castles in life that you wanted to build, but never could because of lack of talent or not winning the gene lottery. It's for the sled rides that didn't have a deadline connected with them, only the sheer joy of feeling the wind in your hair as you lost your mittens and scarf, going so fast down the hill your parents would have a heart attack if they saw it. And nothing could rival the biggest, burning smile that stemmed from your soul and materialized in full between your ears.

It's for your kids, to enjoy something else than generic Zombie Killer Survivalz, Call of Modern Warfare Crapsh|t Ultimate Edition 3, or FIFA Overpaid License Lawyer Edition. It's pure and simple in the most beautiful form. It's for you to take a sneak peak at and play after the kids have gone to bed and you no longer have to pretend to be an adult. It's for you to link back to a better time. It's for all your hopes and dreams that went away so easily, and were beyond your grasp for the longest time.

Marvin's Mittens will grab your wrinkled hand, and inch by snowy inch carry you through what you initially thought would be some hand drawn images, but turning out to be as close to a Winter Holiday with Calvin and Hobbes that you will ever be so lucky to get. Go and play in the snow. Lose a mitten or two along with your worries. It will mend your silly, tired heart and make you smile - for real this time.

This game is about the cutest thing I've ever seen.  If you have children between 6 to 8 years old, this is a perfect platformer for them to get started on.  The graphics, atmosphere, music, and the little bit of writing and dialog that there are, all add up to make a great child's game.
There are no bad guys to defeat, no pits of spikes to traverse and no health bar or damage from falling from too high: simply the wonder of discovery as Marvin wanders out of his backyard in search of his stolen mitten.  Along the way, he meets magical elves who aid in his quest.  Marvin occasionally spies small animals, and if he moves slowly, he can whip out his sketchbook and draw a picture of them.
After about ten or fifteen minutes of playing, Mom calls Marvin back to the house for bed at which point she hums a short lullaby and gives the opportunity to save progress and quit.
The only con is that the last couple of levels, or screens, have one or two really difficult spots for small kids to handle.  It will probably require an adult or older sibling to get the child to the very end and discover who stole Marvin's mitten.  But the simple and heartwarming ending is well worth the effort.

It hit me almost immediately: The colours, the sounds, even the isolation. But it's not just for children, and in fact I'd say the incredible sense of nostalgia it engenders makes it more appropriate, and almost certainly more effective, for adults.

39297601.review:
This is a fun and cute, albeit short game. You have the chance to explore a unique and fun area, starting from your house each day. You have a limited time to explore before your mom calls your name to come home so you have to make the most of your exploring each day. You get to explore forests, mountains, caves, and other areas, all set in a beautiful winter landscape. There are no enemies to fight, no weapons to use, and no skills to level up. This is just a relaxing way to spend a few hours looking for your lost mitten. You also have the chance to collect items and see some rare animals. The animals you find can be added to your sketchbook. The snowflakes you collect allow you to jump higher and race your sled faster across the snow. This game will take you back to your childhood when you would go out tobogganing all day and come home with your lips frozen. But boy did you have a fun day.

The graphics and artwork are incredible as everything was hand drawn. The music is perfect for the winter setting. The game is a nice break from the other more intense games out there. The game also does not take itself to seriously or pretend to be something it is not. It is meant to be a nostalgic trip back to when your big worry would be to maximize your fun before dark and find a lost mitten. Ah to have those days back! Do yourself a favour and try this little gem.

9/10
